snippet.title: 5 things to do in Canberra this weekend
snippet.content:
Our pick of what to do in Canberra this weekend. 1. GAMMA.CONPhoto: Rohan Thomson Dust off those cosplay outfits - GAMMA.CON returns to Canberra this Saturday and Sunday at AIS Arena. The huge celebration of pop culture includes free play video games and board games, live stage acts, workshops, panels, art and crafts, artists, comics, screenings of movies, anime and cartoons, vendors selling toys and collectables, competitions, and cosplay. There's also GAMMA @ Night on Saturday from 6pm for the over 18s with cocktails, comedians, and burlesque, plus mature gaming and screenings. Tickets available at . 2. CANBERRANG â€‹Canberra's annual festival of swing dance Canberrang is on Thursday to Sunday, with events stretching across ten locations. On Saturday from 11am, Garema Place will be filled with the sounds of the Canberra Big Band and a large group of swing dancers. On Sunday, the performance moves to the Old Bus Depot from 11am-noon. Both are free to watch - you can even join in. For all events and ticketing details, see . 3. ELVIS NIGHT @ NFSA
Get out your blue suede shoes Friday night for an Elvis-themed evening at the National Film and Sound Archive, to mark the 40th anniversary of the death of The King himself. From 5.30pm there's an Elvis-themed edition of the Vinyl Lounge - take along your favourite LPs or just sit back and listen. Free entry. Then from 7.15pm, Elvis: That's the Way it is, will screen in the Arc Cinema. The documentary follows the King's 1969 concert comeback, will screen in the Arc Cinema. Tickets $5 from . 4. TOWERS OF TOMORROW
You will now receive updates from
AM & PM Update Newsletter
AM & PM Update Newsletter
Get the latest news and updates emailed straight to your inbox.
See 20 of the world's biggest skyscrapers from Australia, Asia, Canada, USA and the United Arab Emirates, constructed from LEGO bricks at the National Museum of Australia's Towers of Tomorrow exhibition. The impressive creations are constructed by the southern hemisphere's only certified LEGO professional, Australia's Ryan McNaught. If they inspire you, you can also sit down and create your own towers with over 200,000 loose bricks available to play with. The exhibition is ticketed, with 45-minute sessions on the hour from 9.15am-4.15pm. Tickets $5-$10 from . The exhibition runs daily until October 8. 5. BANGARRA DANCE THEATRE Inspired by true events, Bennelong is a new contemporary dance work by Bangarra, choreographed by artistic director Stephen Page. Bennelong highlights the curiosity and diplomacy that led an Aboriginal community to survive a clash of cultures. It's on at Canberra Theatre Centre Thursday, Friday and Saturday at 7.30pm, with a show also on Saturday at 1.30pm. Tickets from .
